subtitle: Thinking Allowed, conversations on the leading
edge of knowledge and discovery with psychologist
Jeffrey Mishlove. Hello and welcome. I'm Jeffrey
Mishlove. Today we'll be talking about what is
probably the most significant UFO sighting of the 1990s, a case that occurred in Rura
Zimbabwe in which over 60 school children observed an unidentified object landing in
their neighborhood and some small alien beings
emerging from the craft and interacting with
the school children. My guest is Randall Nickerson.
He is the director, co-writer, co-editor,
cinematographer, investigative researcher, and
producer of the film Ariel Phenomenon. He began
his career as a stage and film actor. This is a
brand new movie that reviews this very significant
UFO event. Now, I'll switch over to the internet
video. Welcome, Randall. It's a pleasure to meet
you. Pleasure to meet you, Jeff. Thanks for having
me on. I appreciate it. You're very welcome and
just so our viewers know, you're based in Massachusetts. Yes, Massachusetts and New
York City. You're speaking to me from your garage,
right? Right now and I know it's almost the winter
solstice so it must be getting a little chilly
over there. That's true. Yep, it is starting to
feel like winter. Well, I'm very glad to be
with you. I had a chance to view your movie,
Ariel Phenomenon. I have to say it really awakened
me to the significance of an event that was sort
of a passing event in the news. We heard about
it, a UFO scene by dozens of school children in
Zimbabwe, but things like that come and go. You've
really dug into the significance of that event,
looking back at it from a distance of over 20
years. Yeah, I started in 2007. That's when I
got the footage from the John Mack Institute.
They asked me to do a 30-minute DVD and I had
all of John Mack's interviews and those were
absolutely fascinating. And then I was like,
well, I can't just make a film with just a limited amount of material, one source,
even though John Mack was a good source. So I
started to look into, can I find this school?
And it was Nicole Carter I ended up contacting in Zimbabwe who had worked with,
who would also interview these kids at the time.
And everybody else had told me the school had
burnt down, that it wasn't there anymore. And
she said, hey, no, the school is there. And
within two months, right away, I booked a flight
and then tried to prepare myself to go to Africa,
anybody that's been there, it's not a small deal
or a small difference between the United States
or Western countries in Africa. So yeah, and
that brought on all the other people that had
interviewed these children that I had no idea
about. I didn't know about the BBC reporter in
the beginning. So I was at the school in 2008.
That was the first time. And basically, I lived
in Africa for a year and three months total to
track down a lot of the story and the witnesses
and figure out like the sequence of events. I
mean, that that was very important to me, like,
you know, having these interviews is one thing,
but what else happened? Who else was there? Who
else, you know, what was the story? What's what
was the sequence of events? I spent an awful long
time on that. One of the main threads of the
film follows a woman currently living in Toronto,
Canada, who was a grade school child at this
school in Zimbabwe, a fascinating school where
white students and black students and white teachers and black teachers all seem to be
working together in harmony. And 60 of these
children witnessed the UFO and its occupants.
But what I found fascinating is that this woman
living in Toronto 20 some years later was still
haunted by the experience. That's true. And I give
a shout out to her, Emily, because she really,
you know, took a risk like all the other people did in speaking about this.
Yeah, it's I didn't, there were witnesses all over
the world, she happened to be very close to where
I, you know, not too far from me, eight hours.
And I think you find that you, you know, I found
witnesses that do have that trauma, quite a trauma
with it, and then others that don't. And it seems
to be around whether their parents, you know, a
lot of it had to do definitely somewhat with the
experience that they had, but also how they were
treated, whether they're believed or not, or told
not to talk about it at all, which there were quite
a few very religious families at the time that,
you know, didn't want to, you know, had had an
assumption of that it was either made up or that
made up or that it was something evil, which I
think doesn't help us figure this out when we get
into the religious and other areas, we just have
to look at the data. Yeah, there's a religious
belief that these things are demonic. Yeah, and
that's unfortunate because I don't think that's
the case. You know, I just, it happens to many
people of all different types all around the world.
And, you know, I just don't think, I think we're
dealing with something honestly from somewhere
else, not in a religious sense whatsoever, in an
evolutionary sense, we're dealing with something
that's evolved further than us. Just to be honest
with you, a little bit exciting that we have an
example of a species that has gone further and
off their planet, etc. I mean, I think the data
and the people that are coming out now can speak
better to that. But I also wanted to say that,
you know, I know originally the reason that number 60, 62 people at this school came,
it came from the number of drawings that
were made by the kids, the children at Ariel.
Ariel being the name of the school. Correct.
It's sort of a pun that your movie is called
Ariel Phenomenon. Well, I got to put a shout
out to a man, one of the witnesses named Shamba,
who he, during the interview, he, this was in,
this is a long time ago, 2010, 2011. He said,
you know, why don't you, wouldn't Ariel
Phenomenon be a fun name? And I'm like, wow.
And so that came from one of the witnesses
themselves in 2000, 2010. And when I was doing
the England interviews, because I've traveled,
I know it has taken an awfully long time to make
this film, but it's, you know, I had to go to
these places where everybody moved because there
were very few people left in Zimbabwe who
were witnesses. So, in the case of Emily, she,
as I recall toward the end of the film, it points
out she had created maybe 300 drawings. I guess
she was an artist and they were all pretty much
focused on her memories of the UFO and its occupants.
True. Yeah, I mean, she's an incredible artist,
in my opinion. I've watched her paint and,
you know, I, that's one of the ways I've seen
people deal with this. There are many different
ways when people get, you know, after this
incident that they get into adulthood and they
have a way of expressing it or blocking it out,
not wanting to remember it. So, there's two very,
it seems like two very distinct ways people deal with it. But yes, she's,
yeah, it's incredible. She's a plurific, is that the right word? Plurific?
It's a nice word. I'm not sure I've ever heard it before.
I mean, she paints every day, you know. She has an incredible body of work, which is
event-based. I think she'll be a known artist at some point for sure.
When it comes to a UFO sighting of this sort,
there are many dimensions to it. One is simply,
is it a nuts and bolts craft that could be
tracked on radar, photographed? If it landed,
did it leave landing traces? One of the questions
that I was left with after watching your film is
nobody talked about the craft leaving. How did it
get out of there after it had apparently landed
right on the school ground? Well, there were a
couple of children that did comment about that
and basically that it, you know, just zipped off
extremely fast and went toward the village that
was slightly northwest of the school. And there
were a couple we just didn't, we didn't put,
there was so much that, there was so much
material, there's 600 hours a foot. So it was
really hard to put it into an hour and a half.
That was a, that was a real big challenge because
how do you, this story was so, there were so
many witnesses, not just children, adults also,
pilots, like there were so many different perspectives and how, you know, I had to,
unfortunately me, my editor had to really go and make some real tough decisions. And
hopefully I'd love to do the director's cut
where I can make it a, the two and a half hour,
three hour movie that it was meant to really be,
to really give the comprehensive story because
I think the times, dates, you know, where people
were on the playground, all those kind of details
that are really data driven and can be proven
with photographs and stuff like that are really
important. And there were photographs taken of
marks on the ground. There were, there's just an
awful lot that it was seen, something was seen the
night before on two radar systems. One heading,
one was from Mexico city heading toward Africa.
And the other one was the night before from
Johannesburg radar, which is the biggest radar coverage in that part of Africa.
I know at one point you showed a person with
an improvised Geiger counter checking for radio
activity. And as I recall, not really finding anything unusual.
Correct. And, you know, that's not uncommon that
I've found that on some really big cases that
there were, there were no trace. There was no
radiation or, you know, the things you would
think you would find you wouldn't, even though
people saw it, sometimes photographed it or,
you know, videotaped it, but there was no emanation
from it in an electric, in the electromagnetic
spectrum. Let's talk about the occupants. There was at least one that everybody saw.
Multiple people saw too. And this is, you got
to understand, this is a very large playground,
like almost like a college, you know, sports
field, huge. And there's two levels. So I mean,
it's just a beautiful school, in my opinion.
And there were some several, several witnesses
that claim that right in the beginning that there
were four. But the close contact that happened
between the group, the kids that had gathered by the
edge of the playground, that was one specifically
that everybody talks about that came and approached
the children that were gathered looking at this
silver thing. And that's what the closest contact
that I'm aware of was. And I mean, kids were
crying, kids were screaming, kids were just
dumbfounded, you know, from just interviewing them
and interviewing, looking at the archival and
what they said about it, which I would expect.
Which I would expect if you're looking at
something that's from some other evolutionary
path, you know, potentially. And this particular
being, based on the drawings that I saw,
for the most part really resembled the type of being with the large almond-shaped eyes
described by Whitley Strieber, particularly on
the cover of his book, Communion, which was a
bestseller. True. I don't know if people realize,
but 90 percent, it's probably higher than that,
90 percent of all encounter events are these
same biological forms with the big eyes,
larger heads, like 90 percent around the world.
China, Japan, other countries, they're not
reporting something that's extremely different.
There are small cases of that, but the majority
are these small frail-bodied creatures with large
heads and large eyes. The unique thing about Ariel,
which was not common, was that they were dressed in black. Their whatever uniform or
thing, tight-fitting suit that they were wearing
was black. And one of them was reported to have
what looked like hair, but even John Mack, you
know, the kids weren't sure whether it was some
kind of hood covering or something like that. That
was unique, too. And so I did a lot of research,
like, well, where did this show up in other cases,
you know, in the history of going all the way back
to the 1950s? And there's only three that I'm
aware of. So it was very unique in that sense,
you know, because part of me was going on the
possibility of, like, well, where did they get
this story? If they made it up, where did they
get it? And there's so much information in the
Ariel School events story that doesn't fit anything
that was in the media or anything like that. So
that made it unique in itself and kind of said
there's no way they could have made this up
because they didn't have that information. You
know, it wasn't like, and also in Zimbabwe at
that time, it wasn't like they had access to a lot
of that information even today. So yeah, there's,
it's a very interesting case. I still think about
it every day. You know, I think about little
details and like, hmm. What were some of these
unique features? The way they behaved, what they
were wearing, the time, the way time seemed to
be manipulated in some way. Some of the children
talked about their, the way their head was sort
of stiff, like their neck was not free, you know,
in a way that we have our necks and, you know, it was much more rigid.
You know, there's the description they gave.
There was no real talk or videotape about that
literally until 2011, 2012. So a lot of those
details, they weren't even in the media.
Every, you know, in 94, people were talking
about gray aliens and gray suits and, you know,
the same configuration, large head, large eyes,
oval eyes. But yeah, there were some very unique
things, which I'd love to have put in the movie.
But, you know, my editor, he's like, they're not,
nobody's going to understand what those mean,
you know, those differences. But there's a,
there's a file of them that I took aside saying, this is, this doesn't fit.
I know some of the children describe the craft
itself as shimmering, silvery, but almost like
it had a watery texture and that it would sort
of move around. It would be in one location,
it would be in another location and it was not
entirely clear that it was a physical craft.
Yeah, there's no question about that. There were,
you know, it depended on where the kids were
because again, it was such a large playground
that there was an upper field that you were
quite a distance away from where this thing
was initially seen. And then there was the pool
area, which is hundreds of yards away. And people
saw it from that perspective. And then also people
who are, you know, a large group of kids had
gathered right very close to, you know, within
100 yards or so of it. So you had a lot of different perspectives. And each one, which
is fascinating is each one of these children
had a unique experience, you know, and how they
described it, just like any child describing
anything, it's going to be kind of, you know,
how they perceive it with what they know and
what they can compare it to in their own heads.
So, but it did move. That's true. It went from
one position to another position, at least once.
Is it a physical thing? I would have to say,
I believe so. And I think all those children
believe the same thing, or most of them, because
somebody actually went and interviewed those
children years later, like three years later, and
asked those children, do you think this was real
or a vision? Asked 43 children that question. And I
think it was 40, 40 out of the 43 said it was real.
So, and I don't, some of those kids didn't even understand what the person was asking.
You know, what is, what's the difference between
real and a vision? But he would try to explain it.
But I think it's, I think what we're dealing
with is a nuts and bolts thing. It's just the
it's just the technology that brings it, that surrounds it, makes it appear
that it's in some other realm, which, if this is
what we're hearing and what's been going on for
all these years, that they have their literally
their own atmosphere around the craft itself.
Which allows them to go through different mediums,
space, water, it doesn't matter because it's
essentially its own planet. The occupant was
sometimes described as moving in slow motion
or even gliding over the ground. Correct. Yeah.
But probably the most interesting report, and this
is the one that John Mack brought out, because he
made a point of interviewing the students about
their internal experiences, whereas other
interviewers were more looking for the external
facts of the experience. Many of the children
reported having a sense of what I would call
telepathic contact with this alien being. Yes.
I believe that really happened. Several have
talked about that. Some of those people are in the
movie, and then there's a whole bunch of others
who would not, we're not willing to go on camera
to talk about that. Mostly men, mostly the males,
to be honest. But there's no question in my mind
after interviewing people who didn't want to talk
about it, yet told me the very same thing those
other kids had received. Yeah. Told me that that
really did happen. And that was probably, I mean,
what their purpose for being there, I'm not quite
sure what brought them to that location at that
particular time. And there's been talk about that
there's uranium mines in Zimbabwe. There was one
not very far away from the school. There was one
northwest of it that's probably 20 miles away. But
to me, that kind of factual stuff, other people
have brought that forward, isn't as important as
maybe they were there, but why did they do that to
primary school kids? And why did they leave this
message, like this telepathic communication,
warning us about what we were doing to our own
planet? I mean, that's pretty heavy duty to dump
on children. But again, those children have grown
up with that consciousness in mind, and I don't
think any one of them that I know has forgotten
that. Another fascinating thing that you cover
is that that message was spread all over the
world. The media picked up on that remarkably.
I mean, it was short-lived, I think, because of
the news cycle. But for a week or two, or maybe
even a few months, the international news was on
that story. That's true. Yeah, it was all over the
place and then disappeared. There was supposed to
be a documentary made. John Mack was going to do a
documentary soon after all the media died down.
There were reasons that didn't get made. There
was a lot of legal issues and stuff with people
that owned footage, and it never got made. And
to be honest with you, that's why it never got
made until I got onto it. And still, for me,
it was a challenge because of who owned what
footage. Because there were six, seven different
media outlets that also interviewed these kids.
But back to what you were saying about John Mack's
way of interviewing, you're right. I mean, he
went way far deeper because that's what he did.
He spent 20 years as a child psychiatrist. So he
had a lot of experience in it, and he brought out
more of the emotional detail, what was it that
scared you? What was it that made you happy?
What, you know, really focusing on the emotional journey rather than the detail.
I think you see that in a lot of things where
people go for the facts, but sometimes those facts
are buried in the emotion, you know, in the so-to-speak wound because they're attached.
Well, that was his great gift. The irony is,
here you have a pretty ironclad case with so
many witnesses. At the same time, you have deniers
saying it couldn't have happened. It must have
been mass hysteria. John Mack is crazy and he's a
disgrace to Harvard University. It's extraordinary,
the enormous social resistance that John Mack
faced in particular, but certainly not just
John Mack, as I recall, a BBC reporter who covered the story, lost his job, his whole
career with the BBC after that. That's correct.
I think, yeah, a lot of people paid a price at
that time. I mean, I think the times have changed
dramatically since the New York Times at the end
of 2017 and Pentagon people coming out, the
Defense Department saying, you know, these things
are real. We don't know what they are. You know,
things have changed quite a bit, but back in the
90s, as you know, was a brutal time and everybody
paid a price one way or the other because at that
point it just seemed ridiculous to people that
aliens would be here and how would they get here,
all those different, and John paid a big price.
He really did, reputationally, his friend circle.
I think that was the hardest part, to be honest
with you, was John was a really well-renowned
psychiatrist. Pulitzer Prize winner. Pulitzer
Prize winner, professor of psychiatry at Harvard
University. He was, you know, everybody wanted to
be around him. And then when he looked into this
subject and couldn't come up with a clinical
diagnosis for these people, and he was working
with others as well, he stood his ground and said,
this is not a psychological problem. This acts
like a real event. And then like his friend circle
just literally disappeared. So he went from,
you know, and that I know hurt because it not only affected him, it affected his wife
and his family because they were the pinnacle
at Harvard, you know, and then all of a sudden
John is pointing out this abnormality in this
of these events and that they don't fit into any
category. And then, you know, nobody wanted
to accept that at all, particularly Harvard.
Well, of course, one of the confusing areas concerning this debate is, on the one hand,
you've got sightings. And the sighting that
you describe in Zimbabwe seems unquestionably
authentic. On the other hand, there are the abductions. And the evidence and support of
the abductions is much more subjective. Subjective
how? In the sense that it comes from the
personal reports of the experiencers with very limited corroborating evidence.
Sort of. But I mean, a lot of those events are witnessed by other people as well,
friends, girlfriends, people that are close to
those people. I don't know if people know that,
but, you know, unfortunately, the abductions,
things that he was covering. I mean, people
know very little about the information he was
actually receiving and witnesses to those events.
You know, that I hope that actually starts to surface more because that's what makes a
difference. You know, it's not somebody in
their room and, you know, they're just having
a one-off experience that could be labeled as
anything. It's the fact that there are witnesses.
Well, as a matter of fact, I've done a couple
of interviews with Ralph Blumenthal, who
written the book about John Mack and the abduction
cases. And I'm certainly not trying to discount
the evidence completely, but some of those
cases were actually fabricated. They weren't
all legitimate. So, it created an aura of
confusion. And just for the benefit of viewers,
I'm going to link to the earlier interviews about John Mack done by Ralph Blumenthal,
who wrote a book about him. Sure. And I think that doesn't surprise me,
that there would be fabrications in this kind of
phenomenon or, you know, mystery, so to speak.
And, you know, doing research through that,
because when you look at this whole subject,
you really have to look at the whole subject.
And there are certain things that you definitely
delve into. And there are certain things you're
like, yeah, I don't think so. And there are
many, many, many credible people that I've met
and who've told me in complete privacy about what
has happened to them. And then there are people
where I go, I don't know if I don't, you know,
if you actually saw that, wouldn't you have a reaction to that? So, I agree there is,
I don't know what you're referring to fabrications,
but I've seen that in my own research.
Well, everybody draws a line in terms of how
far they're willing to accept something. And I'm
probably much more open than most people to a
phenomenon of high strangeness. And John Mack
was certainly open to phenomena of high strangeness. But even for me, there's some
places I won't go to. They're just too much for
me. And I know everybody has a line somewhere in
the sand. Myself included, and I appreciate that.
It's good. I mean, you know, the way I see it is
I go and establish like, okay, there's enough
people that can testify to this, who saw this.
So, we'll start from there. And then you go, well,
what about the abductions? And then, you know,
there's, it goes way deeper than that, you know,
that the government's working with them, you know,
there's all kinds of things. And, but you, yeah,
I try to be open-minded, but I'm looking like,
if I hear about something, I go there. I don't
take somebody's word for it. I go there and I
talk to people that live there, talk to people
that were involved there, you know, on several
other cases, just to see what is the truth, you know, what's the actual truth here.
There was one interesting scene in your movie
in which, I want to understand it better,
but it appeared as if Emily, I believe it was
a woman from Canada who returned to visit the
school, the aerial school in Zimbabwe, was talking
to a man who seemed to be knowledgeable about the
local folklore or religious traditions and that
there had been quite a lot of lore about spiritual
beings associated with certain locations near
the school, maybe someplace that looked like,
sort of like a cave or an enclosed area of
rocks. And she went there with him to explore,
was there a connection? The natives, Shona, that's the tribal group, yeah?
I wasn't aware of this the first time I went
to the school. I've been there three times.
And so, but he said that the entire school on
three sides of it were surrounded by ancient,
like some of the oldest burial sites of chiefs
in Zimbabwe all around the school. The school
sort of sits right in the middle of it. So the chief was, and I heard this from others
that lived in that village, that that's why they
came. This is their belief is they came because
this was, they were coming to where the tribal
elders from hundreds and hundreds of years ago
were buried. I mean, I don't know the truth
of it, but there's a lot of belief about these
particular creatures. They've seen them before.
It's not new to them. That's what fascinated me
about that whole thing was in other chiefs and other parts of Africa that I talked to.
I mean, when I told them the story, they're
like, of course, we know them. We've seen them.
You know, we used to think that one of the things
that was said was we used to think they were gods,
you know? And that, you know, for thousands
of years, they used to think they were gods.
And it wasn't until in the last 50 years they
figured out that they weren't gods. They were
using technology. So it kind of shifted a lot of
these chiefs' mindsets that, and what they were
also, what they were doing to people. And there's
still people in Zimbabwe and other places in
Africa that put their beds on blocks to raise it above these creatures' height.
I swear to God, I saw it. And so they believe,
a lot of the native Shona and others, some Zulu,
believe that if their bed is raised, they won't
be able to take them. Because that's what happens.
They get taken at night. I mean, there's just so many, I mean, we have the American
understanding of what abductions are and how they happen. But when you go to Africa
and you hear the same story, and they're actually
taking actions to try to make it not happen,
but it's the same thing. That's stunning. That
was stunning to me, to talk to the chiefs and
people that live there. They're dealing with it.
And they have a very interesting perspective of
it, you know, that we don't, we just don't pay
attention to that, unfortunately. But there is
something important to the tribal, the animism,
the people who have been there for thousands of
years. They've been dealing with it. And they have
this passing down of knowledge. And that's been
part of it, that these things are here and they exist.
Well, certainly, one UFO researcher has focused
on this is Jacques Valle, who was recently
interviewed on this channel about another sighting,
not well known until recently, that occurred in
1945, within 20 miles and 20 days of the first
atomic explosion here in New Mexico, where I'm
located. Again, in that sighting and in several
others, the occupants are described as short.
You have these third, fourth, fifth graders describing the occupants as around the same
size as they were. Yeah. Jacques Valle has done
some amazing work. I really, I met him once and
just, yeah, that's great that he's, I didn't know about that case until recently.
The book was only released a few years ago now, Trinity, now in a second edition.
And there's so much evidence around the nuclear,
their interest in what we're doing with nuclear
weapons. And that totally makes sense, actually.
And that's one of the things I think about is
maybe, since it's a planet killer, their concern
may not just be about human beings. This is a
huge biosphere with millions of species that are
probably not common on other planets that may
support life. So, and that we have developed,
us big monkeys here, have developed a technology
that's extremely dangerous to everything. So
maybe, I don't know, I just, there definitely
is enough evidence that I've seen and people
I've talked to who've worked at these, you know,
nuclear facilities, and it kind of makes sense
that they would be paying very close attention
to that. It also makes sense if they happen to
come from a civilization that has a very advanced
technology, far more advanced than our most
advanced systems of our most advanced countries
that they may have been coming here for a
long time. I feel that's, just from the native
conversations I've had out west in the Four Corners area in Africa, even Alaska. Yeah,
they've been around for a long, long time, thousands.
I mean, there's chiefs that I spoke to Zulu,
Credo Mutwa, you know, he was, they've been here for thousands of years.
And you find this not just amongst the Zulu and other African cultures,
you find it pretty much amongst indigenous people worldwide.
Yeah, the Aborigines in Australia, South America.
Yeah, enormous history in places like Peru and
amongst the Quechua, Indians high in the Andes
Mountains. Well, Randall, this has been a pleasure
to speak with you. I want to complement you on
working so hard and diligently over a period, it
sounds like, of more than a decade, close to 15
years to get this film out. Yeah, thank you.
I really do appreciate it. And I got to say,
before we leave, that I did watch some, you know,
in the making of this film, interviews that you
did a long time ago with Dr. John Mack and others. And I really appreciate your work
and dedication that you've done for an awfully long time. Thank you, Randall. And
